user_information: This reader appreciates well-written stories, especially those that blend humor with poignant themes; they are not afraid of shedding tears for a book. They are drawn to narratives featuring cultural experiences and historical backdrops, but also enjoy lighthearted, picaresque adventures reminiscent of Forrest Gump. Audiobooks with excellent narration earn extra points from them. Overall, they seek stories that are both thought-provoking and thoroughly enjoyable, and aren't shy about awarding a top rating when a book delivers.
item_information:
**Book Title**: The Sugar Queen
        **Genre & Themes**: fiction, magical-realism, favorites, chick-lit, romance, fantasy, contemporary
        **Average Reader Rating**: 3.98
        **Story Overview**: In this irresistible novel, Sarah Addison Allen, author of the New York Times bestselling debut, Garden Spells, tells the tale of a young woman whose family secrets--and secret passions--are about to change her life forever.
Josey Cirrini is sure of three things: winter is her favorite season, she's a sorry excuse for a Southern belle, and sweets are best eaten in the privacy of her closet. For while Josey has settled into an uneventful life in her mother's house, her one consolation is the...
        **Written by**: Sarah Addison Allen
        **First Published**: 2008
true_review: Light, fluffy and, to be honest, a little bit weird.
predicted_review: The Sugar Queen was a delightful blend of humor and heartfelt moments that kept me engaged from start to finish. I loved the magical realism woven into Josey's story, and the Southern charm added a lovely backdrop. The characters felt real and relatable, and I found myself laughing and tearing up in equal measure. The narration was top-notch, making it an even more enjoyable experience. A sweet treat of a book that I wouldn't hesitate to recommend!

retrieved_interactions.content:
**Book Title**: The Girl Who Was Saturday Night
        **Genre & Themes**: fiction, canadian, favorites, canada, contemporary, book-club, canadiana
        **Average Reader Rating**: 3.8
        **Story Overview**: Heather O'Neill charmed readers in the hundreds of thousands with her sleeper hit, Lullabies for Little Criminals, which documented with a rare and elusive magic the life of a young dreamer on the streets of Montreal. Now, in The Girl Who Was Saturday Night, she returns to the grubby, enchanted city with a light and profound tale of the vice of fame and the ties of family.
Nineteen years old, free of prospects, and inescapably famous, the twins Nicholas and Nouschka Tremblay are trying to...
        **Written by**: Heather O'Neill
        **First Published**: 2014
retrieved_interactions.true_review: A strange little story containing oddball, downtrodden sibling characters, who were raised in a dysfunctional show biz family, virtually unknown to anyone outside their home province. They are now "adults", but their behaviour doesn't reflect it. The entire family seems to be perched on the precipice of a mental breakdown of epic proportion. Interwoven with intense dissatisfaction with their lives, political reference that I fear only a Canadian would understand, and bizarre appearances by neighbourhood cats that I can't quite figure out, the writing is gritty and edgy but contains a level of metaphor that goes beyond my ability or desire to figure out.

retrieved_interactions.content:
**Book Title**: The Night Circus
        **Genre & Themes**: fantasy, favorites, fiction, ｆａｖｏｒｉｔｅｓ, book-club, romance, historical-fiction
        **Average Reader Rating**: 4.03
        **Story Overview**: The circus arrives without warning. No announcements precede it. It is simply there, when yesterday it was not. Within the black-and-white striped canvas tents is an utterly unique experience full of breathtaking amazements. It is called Le Cirque des Reves, and it is only open at night.
But behind the scenes, a fierce competition is underway - a duel between two young magicians, Celia and Marco, who have been trained since childhood expressly for this purpose by their mercurial instructors....
        **Written by**: Erin Morgenstern
        **First Published**: 2012
retrieved_interactions.true_review: Fantasy or magical fiction is not a genre I usually read. Honestly, I bought the book based wholly in the cover art and the way it felt in my hand. But even so, I did enjoy the writing and some of the characters. I do, however, think that I have likely fulfilled my fantasy requirements for the next year or two...

retrieved_interactions.content:
**Book Title**: My Name Is Memory
        **Genre & Themes**: fantasy, historical-fiction, chick-lit, paranormal, book-club, adult-fiction, reincarnation
        **Average Reader Rating**: 3.7
        **Story Overview**: From the New York Times-bestselling author of The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pantsand The Last Summer (of You and Me)comes an imaginative, inspired, magical book-a love story that lasts more than a lifetime. 
Daniel has spent centuries falling in love with the same girl. Life after life, crossing continents and dynasties, he and Sophia (despite her changing name and form) have been drawn together-and he remembers it all. Daniel has "the memory", the ability to recall past lives and recognize...
        **Written by**: Ann Brashares
        **First Published**: 2010
retrieved_interactions.true_review: I think if I had tried to read this book in print, it might have left me very confused. As it is, the audiobook reduced some of the back and forth in time confusion, by implementing separate narrators in the different time sequences.The premise of the story, two lovers travelling in time, being reborn and passing each other, sometimes connecting and sometimes not, was a tantalizing one. The idea of repeated reincarnation and reconnecting with people we have loved before, in order to right the wrongs we have done one another, is certainly very compelling. Overall, a pleasing listen even though, by the end, I just wanted them to "get on with it." Good writing, but the story became a little weighted down and monotonous after passing through 1500 years from start to finish.
